captions.text:
Vsauce, I'm Jake and come in here - there
is a giant prehistoric sea monster that absorbed

massive amounts of radiation roaming the streets.
In fact, he's been called The King of Monsters

because Godzilla is incredibly...large. Here
have a menu. According to Legendary Pictures

Godzilla is 355ft tall, 50ft taller than the
Statue of Liberty, and weighs 90,000 tons

- imagine a cruise ship...with legs...standing
upright. But it raises the question if a creature

of that scale is possible...Could Godzilla
Exist?

At 90,000 tons Godzilla is a very big thing,
a thing that would need about 215 million

calories a day. It is estimated that the adult
human body has 110,000 calories so if Godzilla

had a taste for people he would need to devour
1,950 of them every day, increasing the global

mortality rate by 1.3%, or he could just eat
826,000 Waffle Tacos.

So has there been any living thing that comes
close to Godzilla's weight? Well, I made a

chart. At the bottom of the scale we have
a human being, I used a completely accurate

unphotoshopped image of myself as representation,
at 2.2 tons the saltwater crocodile which

is the heaviest reptile, at 11 tons the heaviest
land animal - the African Bush Elephant, then

the heaviest animal to have ever existed the
blue whale at 209 tons. For heaviest organism

that we know of there's the Pando, a clonal
colony of Aspen trees, at 6,600 tons...13.6

times less than Godzilla. He actually weighs
a little over half of all the gold we have

ever mined. Not only that, but he is 295ft
taller than the Sauroposeidon, the tallest
dinosaur yet discovered.

In addition to Godzilla being the heaviest
living creature, he would also be the tallest

and, including his tail, the longest. Fortunately
for us, we wouldn't need bullets or missiles

to take down The King of Monsters, just gravity
and the square-cube law.

Let's say this cube is bone and the area of
it's face is 1cm^2, giving it a volume of

1cm^3. If we want to double the size the area,
it's strength, multiplies by 4 but it's volume,

thus it's weight and mass, multiplies by 8
. As you continue to scale up, the bones get

bigger faster than they get srronger, eventually
weighing more than they can support and the
whole thing would collapse under the pressure.

This can be seen to a degree with Robert Wadlow,
the tallest human being in recorded history.

At 8ft 11in tall and 440lb, he had to wear
leg braces and use a cane because his legs

had trouble supporting the rest of him. He
passed away from an infected blister on his
foot due to poor blood circulation.

And that is another issue: blood pressure.
The taller and larger you are, the more powerful

your heart would have to be to successfully
fight gravity and send blood throughout your
body at a consistent rate.

In the ocean, Godzilla would fare a bit better
since the water helps support that weight

- it's why whales can be as large as they
are - but once emerging from the depths and

stepping foot onto the beach, he'd sink into
the Earth due to the immense foot pressure,

his bones and cartilage would give out under
his weight, and his body slamming against

the ground would be the extent of the destruction.
We'd also be able to make about 350 handbags

from his feet. Since pain travels through
the nervous system at around 2ft per second,

Godzilla would be dead on the ground before
the signal could reach his brain.

According to Paleontologist Dr. Mike Taylor,
even a Godzilla at 1/8th the size would still
collapse under the pressure.

But let's say Godzilla could walk around and
cause destruction to a city like New York,

how much would that damage cost? My friends
at Cinema Sins made a video detailing just

that and I definitely recommend checking it
out. Especially since we don't have to live

in fear of a huge monster stepping on our
fleshy bodies, so we can spend more time watching

videos or enjoying the giant creature free
outside world. And, as always, thanks for
watching

comments.text:
I would also assume that part of Godzilla's mass would be Boron-10 isotopes.
When Godzilla absorbs external radiation, he charges up electrically 
(Boron-10 decaying into Boron-11 + alpha particle + neutron into Lithium-7 
with an energy release of 2.31 MeV (2.31 Million electron Volts).  And with 
this excess of energy, Godzilla converts internal sea water into reactive 
hydrogen which activates the internal sulfide rocks into Hydrogen Sulfide 
(and hydrochloric acids, sulfuric acids, and other useful digestive 
substances).  Note that Godzilla, being a living radioactive marshmallow 
balloon can lift his own mass by using the hydrogen for buoyancy in air.
I would suspect that Godzilla can also make usage of the inert Helium, 
Neon, Argon, and Krypton for other useful internal reaction control 
dampening purposes or for storing electrons for later usage on short-term 
to long-term scales.

http://web.mit.edu/nrl/www/bnct/info/description/description.html
Boron-10 in or adjacent to the tumor cells disintegrates after capturing a 
neutron and the high energy heavy charged particles produced destroy only 
the  cells in close proximity to it, primarily cancer cells, leaving 
adjacent normal cells largely unaffected.﻿
comments.author: Matrix29bear

comments.text:
As for Godzilla's size.  What happens if Godzilla is chock full of inert 
gases like helium or neon.  You ASSUME that Godzilla is merely MASSIVE 
(mass = weight), but you fail to consider VOLUME DENSITY.  Godzilla could 
be a thick-skinned meaty marshmallow balloon of cells blown up like 
individual tiny helium balloons.  Ever try to punch a marshmallow?  Now 
wrap each marshmallow individually in a bit of Saran Wrap.  Now try it.  
The less dense the meat, the less meat needed, the less muscle mass 
required to move it all.  By the way, Hydrogen Sulfide = explosive 
flammable human-zombie-making.  Godzilla's majority of mass would be water, 
helium, hydrogen sulfide, sulfur-rich rock bits, a huge amount of heavy 
metals sparsely distributed, radioactive isotopes, extremophile bacteria, 
probably deep sea tube worms, and mostly hollow cellular mass which 
resemble metallic leather balloons.﻿
comments.author: Matrix29bear

comments.text:
You're overlooking DEEP SEA TUBE WORMS.
These creatures survive without sunlight or consumption of organic matter.
Godzilla could be a huge collection of EXTREMOPHILE organisms which excrete 
large amounts of flammable hydrocarbons which Godzilla expels through his 
mouth (the equivalent of pooping for an organically-fed organism).
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giant_tube_worm
With sunlight not available directly as a form of energy, the tubeworms 
rely on bacteria in their habitat to oxidize hydrogen sulfide, using 
dissolved oxygen in the water as electron acceptor. This reaction provides 
the energy needed for chemosynthesis. For this reason, tube worms are 
partially dependent on sunlight as an energy source, since they use free 
oxygen, which has been liberated by photosynthesis in water layers far 
above, to obtain nutrients. In this way tubeworms are similar to many forms 
of life which live in the ocean below depths that sunlight can penetrate. 
However, tubeworms are unique in being able to use bacteria to indirectly 
obtain all materials they need for growth from molecules dissolved in 
water. Tube worm growth resembles that of hydroponically grown fungi more 
than it does that of typical animals which need to "eat".﻿

comments.author: DCMagnum101

comments.text:
I actually did a project on this recently for a college biology course. I 
estimated the cross-sectional area of Godzilla's femur, and concluded that 
in order to function effectively as a skeleton for an animal that large, 
the bone would have to be able to withstand pressures in excess of 400 
gigapascals. If Godzilla's bones were made of tungsten they could actually 
support his weight and the stresses of movement without much issue, but 
tungsten isn't exactly a common element, and getting enough of it to make a 
skeleton out of would be practically impossible. But luckily, there are 
other options.

As Godzilla grows in size, the pressure inside his bones would at some 
point, long before maximum size is reached, reach the levels necessary to 
synthesize diamonds. If the bones have a source of free carbon, and some 
way of producing large amounts of heat for short periods of time, like 
microscopic air bubbles, which would give off heat when compressed by the 
pressure from the animal's movement, then diamonds would begin to form 
within the bones, providing the ultimate structural reinforcement at the 
points where it's needed the most, without jeopardizing the bone's natural 
bone-like qualities.

I'm not saying that this is in any way likely to happen (there have been 
millions of species of animal that have lived on earth and none of them had 
diamonds in their bones), but if it somehow were to happen, then an animal 
the size of Godzilla could easily become mechanically plausible. In fact, I 
calculated that a truly specialized species with this kind of reinforcement 
could, under 1G of gravity, reach a height of nearly 3,000,000 kilometers, 
about twice the diameter of the sun, before its bones would start to 
collapse under its weight, which, at that size, would be the least of its 
worries. Before it got to that point, the pressure inside its body would 
have caused the atoms within it to undergo sustained nuclear fusion, 
causing it to explode from the inside out and collapse, turning it into the 
bloodiest star in the universe.

That would happen BEFORE its skeleton was ever in danger of collapsing 
under the animal's weight. So as unlikely as this scenario is, it's not 
COMPLETELY impossible.﻿

comments.author: menotsane75

comments.text:
You make a lot of assumptions here - and much of what you say here is based 
entirely on the assumption that Godzilla's internal structure - and 
skeletal /muscular structure, cellular structure, etc, are composed of the 
same basic kind of cells found in other animals on Earth. However, it 
doesn't account for the possibility that life - somewhere out there in the 
universe - might - just might - exist in a way we are not familiar with. We 
tend to model life - and all its possibilities - on what we see around us 
on Earth. But there's no reason to suppose that life - down to the cellular 
level  and even down to having very different kinds of blueprints than the 
DNA we are used to - might be fundamentally different in construction 
elsewhere. 

So I think the better response to the question "Could Godzilla exist" 
(which carries with it the assumption and the implied question - could he 
exist as a life form as WE know life) would actually be "What KIND of 
makeup would Godzilla need to have in order to exist? How would he have to 
differ from all life as we understand it?"

Suppose he has a cell structure similar to graphene, which is a honeycomb 
matrix of carbon atoms arranged on the atomic scale in such a way that it 
provides even a very thin sheet of the material with IMMENSE strength. As 
in, you could put a few tons concentrated onto a single point of it and it 
wouldn't break even if the sheet of it were paper thin. So now imagine 
Godzilla's skin and other parts composed of such an arrangement of carbon 
atoms. We're carbon-based lifeforms to begin with. 
Now if you extend that to his skeletal structure, you have an ULTRA-strong 
support structure capable of even supporting thousands of tons, especially 
the bones consist of something akin to a honeycomb, cross-braced structure 
made from things similar to carbon nanotubes.

As for how much he'd have to eat, this also assumes a metabolism and 
physiology like our own and not an entirely unknown type of organism. 

Godzilla is fictional. So it stands to reason he may be composed of 
as-of-yet fictional materials that function in fictional ways. No sense in 
applying what we know about our world to him, because if he's built like 
real animals, of course he can't exist. ﻿

comments.author: Steven Lewis

comments.text:
True, Roper's description of the square-cube law only applies to structures 
that scale isometrically. Large animals get larger by scaling 
allometrically, or by speeding up the growth of some structures over 
others. This is why elephant bones are so much thicker than a human bone 
scaled up to the same size. The problem with Godzilla is that even if it 
allometrically scaled up its legs to hold up its immense weight, the 
thickness of the bone and muscle would be so large that there would be no 
space between each leg. It would basically be one large leg. So if Godzilla 
was a stationary animal it would be possible to get to 90,000 tonnes, but 
if it is going to move it needs to do some physical shenanigans to get 
around the scaling problem (for example having muscles that have a stronger 
physiological cross sectional area and having super-dense bones that can 
take the pull and stress of large muscle and immense weight).

raptor does not make him automatically more realistic. Zilla defies the 
square-cube law just as much as the real Godzilla does, plus while Godzilla 
can feed on radiation Zilla supposedly eats fish, and there's nowhere near 
enough fish in the world to keep a creature that size alive. Not to 
mention, the fact that it leans forward so much is even less realistic than 
Godzilla walking upright. Zilla's legs are too small to support its body 
and if it leaned forward like that it would just fall forward on its face.
comments.author: Benjamin Deedrick

comments.author: urborg74

comments.text:
Hey Vsauce3, I really enjoyed the presentation of this video and how 
seamlessly different mathematical concepts were incorporated into this 
simple, yet mystifying question. I loved how this video was able to take 
what some would call a ridiculous question to ponder and apply true logic 
and knowledge in order to answer it. The explanation of the logic used is 
also clear and concise. I really enjoy learning in this particular way. One 
particular concept that caught my eye was the Square-Cube Law. This law 
does make sense to me, as it is logical that as the size of an object 
increases, its volume increases at a faster rate. When this law is applied 
to bones, the volume in comparison to the surface area determines the 
strength of bones. After doing some calculations, I realized that if the 
shape is changed (example: rectangular prism) that the bones get weaker and 
weaker at an even faster rate. When you mentioned that if the force of 
gravity was reduced or Godzilla was a water creature that one could 
survive, I wondered: how much would the force of gravity have to be 
decreased? Or which planet or moon would be a good reference to the 
“correct” force of gravity for Godzilla? ﻿
comments.author: Evan Jones
